report_title: Meat, Beef & Poultry Processing in the US
executive_summary: In recent years, the US Meat, Beef and Poultry Processing industry has shown remarkable resilience and adaptability in response to changing consumer preferences and technological advancements. The sector has effectively managed challenges such as fluctuating raw material costs and regulatory changes while capitalizing on the rising demand for processed and convenience foods. Processors have increasingly turned to technological innovations like automation and robotics to enhance production capabilities and maintain product consistency. These advancements have improved operational efficiency and addressed concerns regarding food safety and quality, thereby boosting consumer confidence in processed meat products. Over the past five years, revenue has grown at a CAGR of 0.8% to $274.8 billion, despite an expected 3.0% drop in 2024. Profit is expected to dwindle to 4.7% of revenue in 2024 from 5.2% in 2019.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Revolutionizing Meat Processing with Advanced Automation
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Robotics and AI have taken over precision tasks like cutting and trimming, minimizing human error and enhancing worker safety. Automation reduces the dependency on manual labor, allowing for a streamlined workforce and potentially lowering operational costs. The use of sensors and data analytics in meat processing has significantly improved the consistency and quality of products. Ongoing training programs are crucial, equipping employees with the necessary skills to manage and maintain sophisticated automation technology.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Elevating Food Safety in Meat Processing
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Enhanced industry standards and stringent regulations ensure the safety and quality of meat products. Adopting state-of-the-art sanitation practices and technologies reduces the risk of foodborne illnesses. Implementations like blockchain technology offer real-time tracking capabilities of meat products throughout the entire supply chain. There is a growing public and industry awareness regarding food safety issues, motivating improvements in processing facilities and practices.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Growing Demand for Processed and Convenience Foods
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The modern consumer's preference for convenience has led to a surge in demand for processed meat products. Items such as pre-packaged cuts and ready-to-cook options have gained popularity, reflecting the desire for effortless meal preparation. Increasingly hectic lifestyles strongly influence the trend toward processed and convenience foods. People continuously seek quick meal solutions to save time, significantly impacting the types of products available on the market. Food processors have responded to this growing demand by developing innovative, value-added products.

There is an increasing awareness of the environmental impacts of meat, beef and poultry processing. Both consumers and regulators are pushing for more sustainable practices, prompting processors to adopt eco-friendly measures throughout their operations. Processors are actively implementing initiatives to reduce their environmental footprint. These efforts include reducing water usage, minimizing carbon emissions and investing in renewable energy sources to create a more sustainable production process.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Rising Meat Consumption Overseas Will Boost Exports
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Meat consumption in the United States is high and stable, so the system to meet demand is efficient and extensive. Emerging markets in overseas countries must build a similar factory farming system or import meat products to satisfy heightened demand from increased per capita disposable income. China is the second-largest importer of US meat products and will soon recover its pork production after several years of African Swine Flu devastation, limiting growth in Asian markets. A depreciating US dollar, measured by the trade-weighted index (TWI), will promote exports as US goods become comparatively cheaper.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Increasing Consolidation Will Boost Revenue for Larger Corporations
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Medium and large meat processors will continue vertically integrating and controlling multiple points in the supply chain, dropping production costs per unit. Meat prices are volatile due to changes in feed prices, so an economy of scale is highly desirable to limit revenue losses brought on by long-term contracts or robust price-based competition. Since new products are almost nonexistent in the industry, revenue growth typically relies on purchasing smaller plants and expanding existing productive capacity.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: THE RISE OF PLANT-BASED MEAT ALTERNATIVES
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Meat processors are actively broadening their portfolios to include various plant-based options, aligning with evolving consumer demands for more sustainable and ethical choices. Significant investments in research and development are being made to enhance the sensory experience of plant-based meats, aiming to match or surpass the quality of traditional meats. Companies are intensifying marketing strategies to highlight plant-based diets' ecological and health advantages, leveraging these benefits to appeal to a broader audience.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: HOW MEAT PROCESSORS ARE PIONEERING ECO-FRIENDLY INNOVATIONS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Meat processing companies increasingly focus on reducing water and energy usage, significantly lowering their environmental footprints. Initiatives are in place to diminish waste production, enhancing sustainability throughout the operational cycle of meat processing. A shift towards compostable and recyclable packaging materials is being adopted to mitigate the environmental impact of product distribution and disposal. Collaboration with sustainable farms is being strengthened to ensure the responsible sourcing of meat products, catering to the growing demand from environmentally conscious consumers.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry slaughter animals, process the carcasses and package the meat into products and byproducts. The industry also purifies and refines animal fat, bones and meat scraps. Products are sold to other food manufacturers, renderers, grocery and meat wholesalers and retail.
key_trends: Ethically sourced grass-fed and grass-finished beef is highly prized.
Consumers increasingly seek this type of beef for its superior quality.
Price is the key factor in competition among businesses. Companies that lower costs through vertical integration can offer more competitive prices and gain an edge.

Stringent safety protocols are critical in meat processing. Enhanced industry standards and strict regulations are designed to ensure the safety and quality of meat products, aiming to protect consumers from potential health risks.
Enhanced precision and safety revolutionize meat processing. Robotics and AI significantly reduce risks by automating tasks, ensuring a safer environment for workers and improving overall efficiency.
Five companies own nearly half of the market share. JBS is the industry's largest operator, and Tyson Foods is the second-largest company.
Lowering emissions and implementing sustainable practices are crucial. These measures not only help avoid EPA fines but also enhance brand reputation.
The USDA and FDA closely monitor the quality of meat. Companies must monitor animal health and product safety to avoid forced compliance.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Meat wholesalers buy high-value-added and specialized meats and distribute them to butchers and supermarkets. Wholesale bypass has lessened this segment's share of revenue over the past five years as larger downstream meat retailers choose to purchase products directly from processors. Meat processors that wish to cut out the middleman benefit from higher per-unit pricing but must keep staff on payroll that can maintain relationships with customers.

Other markets for industry products include retail traders, snack food manufacturers, and frozen food producers. Snack food companies typically purchase the lowest-quality products from processors, such as meat extract, for use in pork rinds or chicken-flavored potato chips. This allows them to create affordable, flavor-rich snacks while maximizing the utility of meat byproducts.

Animal feed production involves creating food for animals, such as livestock and pets, by processing raw materials, including meat byproducts that result from meat processing. Over the past five years, the market for premium pet food has notably expanded as more consumers are increasingly opting for higher-quality options to enhance their pets' nutrition.

Large grocery store chains' local butchers, specialty meat shops, delis, and meat departments buy industry products for resale or use in food preparation. Wholesalers dominate sales to meat markets because they offer a one-stop shop for busy businesses to acquire their varied inventory, making the procurement process more efficient and streamlined for these establishments.

products_and_services.product_description: Meat processed from carcasses represents other processed meat products (except poultry), including frozen and cooked meat products, ham and sausages. These products are a low-cost staple in many consumers' diets and their price accessibility has secured them in the market despite their perception of being less healthy. Due to their relatively low cost, processed meats are often purchased for use in fast-food chains and similar industries.

Rendering and meat byproduct processing consistently account for the smallest share of industry revenue. This segment includes byproducts for use as feed and fertilizers, but the majority comes from demand from pet food manufacturers. Pet food manufacturers have been less inclined to use animal byproducts in production as consumers become more conscious of the quality of pet food.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The price of red meat is an index of all industry products except poultry, so it accounts for the prices of most products sold by meat processors. When red meat prices increase, processors earn higher revenue, but continually high prices may deter some consumers.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Import Competition Has Increased But Remains Low
international_trade_points.trade_description: Over the past five years, imports have grown much faster than exports, revealing a shift towards greater reliance on foreign goods. Despite this increase in imports, a small portion of the domestic demand for meat products is met by international sources, indicating a strong preference or necessity for locally sourced meat products.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Meat Products Are Complicated To Ship Long-Range
international_trade_points.trade_description: Because meat can go bad quickly if not properly stored and transported, a shorter supply chain is helpful to mitigate loss. Canada accounts for the highest portion of imports and producers often export live animals bred and raised in Canada to the United States to finish raising them on low-cost grain. US animal processing plants are typically more efficient than foreign alternatives.

international_trade_points.trade_title: The US Is A Net Exporter Of Processed Meats
international_trade_points.trade_description: Emerging markets overseas, particularly in regions with rapidly growing meat consumption, have increasingly relied on efficient US animal processing plants to meet their demands. With its vast and dense population, China heavily depends on imported food products. It ranks as the second-largest market for US meat, beef and poultry in this sector.

international_trade_points.trade_title: EXPORTS WILL GROW AS THE US DOLLAR DEPRECIATES OVER THE NEXT FIVE YEARS
international_trade_points.trade_description: As the US dollar weakens, US goods become relatively more affordable globally. This economic shift usually stimulates foreign demand, leading to increased exports. However, following a significant surge in 2021, the growth rate of exports will decelerate annually as the initial boost from a weaker dollar begins to stabilize and less dramatic increases in foreign demand occur.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region hosts many meat processing plants, focusing heavily on poultry. Prominent companies such as Tyson Foods, headquartered in Springdale, Arkansas, are key industry companies. Proximity to relevant ports offers Southeastern processors a strategic advantage for exporting poultry to Mexico. This geographical benefit enhances their market reach and operational efficiency.

The Plains region's central location closely integrates with the swine farming industry, allowing processors to be near farmers and ranchers, which reduces transportation costs. Low population density enables lower land costs, minimizing operational expenses. This makes it easier for new companies to establish a presence in the meat processing industry.

The Great Lakes region is a logistical connecting point between agriculture-centric states in the Plains and manufacturing/commerce hubs in the Mid-Atlantic and New England. This strategic location reduces logistics costs for animal farms targeting critical states like New York, Pennsylvania and Massachusetts. It is pivotal, making it the third-largest region for animal processing and slaughterhouses.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The USDA and FDA Inspect for Product Quality and Safety
regulations_points.regulation_description: The USDA enforces stringent standards for the wholesomeness and quality of beef, poultry and other meat products in the US. It conducts inspections throughout the supply chain to ensure compliance. Meanwhile, the FDA enforces product safety, animal health, and consumer information rules.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Processors Have to Comply with Environmental Policies
regulations_points.regulation_description: The EPA and state governments enforce key environmental regulations impacting meat processors, including the Clean Water Act and the Clean Air Act. These laws mandate strict waste disposal and pollution control measures for processing facilities.

basis_points.basis_title: Ethically sourced grass-fed and grass-finished beef is highly prized
basis_points.basis_description: Ethically sourced grass-fed and grass-finished beef is highly prized and in demand from consumers who seek superior quality.

basis_points.basis_title: Price is the key factor driving competition
basis_points.basis_description: Price is the key factor driving competition among businesses. Companies that can lower costs through vertical integration can offer more competitive prices and gain an edge.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Large companies have efficient models and facilities
concentration_points.concentration_description: Large companies have efficient models and facilities that boost market share.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Market Share Concentration is Varied by Product Segment
concentration_points.concentration_description: Beef processing is much more highly concentrated than poultry or swine. Though an antitrust lawsuit prevented JBS from acquiring National Beef Packing Company and becoming the number one beef processor just before the period, this segment is trending towards high consolidation.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases account for roughly two-thirds of revenue
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Raw materials such as livestock, carcasses, feed and packaging tend to see the most price fluctuations during periods of drought or disease. Although purchase costs have declined, they've primarily remained stable as a revenue share over the past five years.
Increasing consolidation among companies has reduced unit costs, intensified price competition among significant businesses and contributed to volatile revenue.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry requires significant capital investment for machinery and facilities, alongside a skilled labor force for operations, thus heightening the financial burden and operational complexity for new businesses attempting to enter the market.

volatility_points.volatility_title: MARKET PRICE FLUCTUATIONS IMPACT REVENUE VOLATILITY
volatility_points.volatility_description: Market price fluctuations in livestock and feed commodities directly impact production costs and selling prices. Factors like weather conditions, global demand shifts, and trade policies influence supply and demand dynamics, affecting pricing.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Regulatory Changes and Compliance Costs Contribute to Volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Changes in food safety regulations and compliance requirements necessitate costly upgrades to processing facilities and procedures. Compliance with environmental standards and animal welfare regulations adds operational complexity and cost.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: NEW TECHNOLOGIES ARE IMPLEMENTED TO IMPROVE EFFICIENCY AND PROLONG SHELF LIFE
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: High-pressure processing is used on packaged goods to enhance their stability and safety, extending shelf life without chemicals. Shockwave processing significantly improves environmental efficiency by reducing energy use.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by rising imports?
FAQs.answer: Rising imports of processed meats (i.e. cured meats) have the potential to threaten domestic companies. Overall, imports don't pose a threat to domestic meat suppliers because of freshness and logistical concerns.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche, or do you produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Most large companies produce a wide range of meat products. Specialized companies typically have higher profit as they primarily deal in delicatessen.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices?
FAQs.answer: Corn and soybean prices affect animal feed prices. Droughts also have the potential to disrupt supply.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing heavily in R&D to meet changing consumer preferences?
FAQs.answer: Companies are looking into meatless products. Tyson, in particular, is investing in alternative meat products.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation?
FAQs.answer: This industry uses a lot of automation. The poultry segment uses the most automation out of all segments.

FAQs.question: Do you use SAP software systems to optimize all aspects of your company's manufacturing, sales, inventory and distribution channels?
FAQs.answer: Meat, beef and poultry processors use software to track production statistics. Meat, beef and poultry processors are increasing their use of technology to boost efficiencies.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Companies use all measures of health and safety practices to mitigate the spread of diseases and viruses. Health and safety requirements play a significant role in this industry because of the sensitive nature of industry products (raw meat).

FAQs.question: Is your company adequately prepared to comply with new environmental standards?
FAQs.answer: In most cases, companies take environmental regulations seriously and face substantial fines for violations. Consumers are more aware of the environmental impact of their meat products.

FAQs.question: How does your company compensate for the seasonality of cashflow?
FAQs.answer: Seasonality occurs during the holiday seasons and during the summer. Companies try to expand and drop production in line with seasonal demand trends (i.e. turkey during Thanksgiving).

FAQs.question: How does input price volatility impact profit?
FAQs.answer: Large jumps in commodity prices can constrain profit. The volatile price of red meat can influence instability in profit among meat, beef and poultry processors.

FAQs.question: What is your historical performance in meeting consumer expectations? What is your current reputation, and how can you improve it? Which of your products are the most popular with customers?
FAQs.answer: The ability to identify consumer requirements and produce goods that satisfy those needs better enables this industry to profit from cost-effective or value-added meat products. It also will help in competition with substitutes.

FAQs.question: How does your company maintain customer satisfaction?
Do major buyers reveal changes in demand?
FAQs.answer: It's vital to be able to identify consumer requirements like nutrition. Conducting market research can help determine these needs and what meat products will meet them.

FAQs.question: Have you invested heavily in automation? What effect does automation have on your profit?
FAQs.answer: The level of capital investment in new plants and equipment can make processing more efficient after slaughter.

FAQs.question: How does the price of red meat impact your business? As prices drop, can you shore up revenue with poultry or other revenue segments?
FAQs.answer: When red meat prices climb, meat, beef and poultry processors tend to earn higher revenue, benefiting the industry. However, perpetual high prices, including during periods of low disposable income, can deter customer purchases and cause revenue to fall. The volatile price of red meat also influences profit.
